item.title: iPhone 5 Lost in Bar again?
item.dc:creator: @Ix_Soulcist_xI Soulcist
item.description:
@Ix_Soulcist_xI wrote:

Taharok:

More features means more maintenance and more likely for something to go wrong. It applies well outside of application development, and is sorta the price you pay for wanting more in an imperfect world.

Yes, I know it can’t be helped, but at least have one side of development for such improvements such as having a development for iPhone 5 and then creating another phone on another development so people won’t be disappointed when the next iPhone is released.

Read full topic

Those phones also did a lot less than phones of today. I’d much rather have today’s Android, iOS and WP7 phones than any of the ones you’re referring to.
[/quote]
Did a lot less - Yes, however, a lot less problems consisted in them - Yes. I have an Android Comet, and it’s not that bad of a phone, but does need some work as all do.[/quote]

More features means more maintenance and more likely for something to go wrong. It applies well outside of application development, and is sorta the price you pay for wanting more in an imperfect world.

item.title: iPhone 5 Lost in Bar again?
item.dc:creator: @Ix_Soulcist_xI Soulcist
item.description:
@Ix_Soulcist_xI wrote:

[quote=“tL, post:16, topic:413042”][quote author=Ix Soulcist xI link=topic=514515.msg3742067#msg3742067 date=1315441135]

huh, what relevance does that have to what you just said?

Because 14 months is not long enough to create an efficient phone, at least not to me.
[/quote]

But pretty much no manufacturer leaves it as long as 14 months to release a new phone. None of the big manufacturers need anywhere near that long, Samsung, HTC, Motorola, Apple, they’re all building each new phone from existing hardware and using existing operating systems with often minor feature upgrades for specific devices (Android phones via skinning (unless we’re talking about nexus devices), iPhones via iOS updates with a new feature of their system only on their new phone).

These are all massive companies with thousands of employees (even if not all working on the phone), they can push out a new phone easily. 14 months is plenty of time, as is 12 months. Besides, all of the manufacturers will be working on other things alongside the release of newer phones that’ll go into phones further out in the future.[/quote]
If that’s the case, wish it would make the damn phones better, Hell the classic phones as a the Nokia in the early 2000s and 1999 or something were a lot better than our recent upgrade for the phones, I didn’t have that many problems as I did with them like I do now, but I hope for the best for the future because I’m sure we’ll do something magnificent or something.

Read full topic

item.title: iPhone 5 Lost in Bar again?
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

[quote=“Ix Soulcist xI, post:14, topic:413042”][quote author=tL link=topic=514515.msg3741936#msg3741936 date=1315437615]
huh, what relevance does that have to what you just said?
[/quote]
Because 14 months is not long enough to create an efficient phone, at least not to me.[/quote]

But pretty much no manufacturer leaves it as long as 14 months to release a new phone. None of the big manufacturers need anywhere near that long, Samsung, HTC, Motorola, Apple, they’re all building each new phone from existing hardware and using existing operating systems with often minor feature upgrades for specific devices (Android phones via skinning (unless we’re talking about nexus devices), iPhones via iOS updates with a new feature of their system only on their new phone).

These are all massive companies with thousands of employees (even if not all working on the phone), they can push out a new phone easily. 14 months is plenty of time, as is 12 months. Besides, all of the manufacturers will be working on other things alongside the release of newer phones that’ll go into phones further out in the future.

Read full topic

Apple needs to release so fast to even hold out any hope of keeping up with Android phones, too bad they still can’t. (simply because there are so many different hardware manufacturers working on Android phones, in addition to all the thousands of people that can work on Android source code, instead of a handful of Apple employees)
